ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Good understanding of micro i think
Fundamental Micro
Critical analysis. I learned so much.
I gained a lot of life skills and some knowledge on general economics.

Supply, demand, labor market, competition, monopolies. A lot of skills in evaluating economic markets and real world trends, and applying economic ideas to many examples in current events and the real world.
I developed my quantitative skills, I better understand the theory behind markets and undertstand the practical implications and examples.
I learned micro-economic principles that will inform my analysis of the world and even my own "rational" decisions in the future.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I really enjoyed this class. but maybe it could have been more clear just what was gonna be on the exam and the curve
Tolga is the strength.
Tolga is a great professor. Tests are weighted very heavily.

The strengths of this course were the concise examples and notes on the board. The weaknesses were that the teacher taught to quickly for me at times, and I was unable to both take notes and understand the material.

The lectures are structured in a way that is focused on application of the concepts to enhance understanding and a deeper level of proficiency with the material. The course could benefit from course/lecture notes being made available, as right now the textbook is the only source of reference when reviewing course material.

Strengths - the professor is passionate, knowledgable and very engaging 
Weaknesses - occasionally the professor will go to fast and will not fully explain mathematical models - there is quite a lot of content to cover in the semester (very rewarding if you manage to grasp all of the content though)

Tolga is an incredibly engaging instructor, who cares about his students learning and success and sprinkles his lessons with insights about life and humor. He has been teaching the course for a long time and is very experienced. I enjoyed the class and learned a lot about econ and its application to real life. I found the intimate class setting much more conducive to my personal learning process than a massive lecture, but it does mean that there is a more challenging grading curve. While having less psets makes the experience throughout the semester better, it could have been nice to get more regular practice to prepare for our midterm and final.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yea tolga rocks
If you need to learn intro micro, Tolga is great. I recommend.
If you want to learn econ, yes. If you want to take a gut, definitely not.

I would recommend this course only to a certain type of student that is good at taking notes and has a natural affinity to the field. I would not recommend this course for someone who learns from discussion or more collaboratively.

Yes! Even if you are not a econ major, this is an excellent course. You will learn so much, and the ideas from econ can be applied elsewhere in life as well. Definitely take this class with Tolga, he makes classes engaging and interesting.
Yes. Even if you are not an economics major it is worth taking this course becuase it will help you to understand much about our world and even help you in other fields where economics is relevant.

I had a great experience, but I think this would depend on what the student is looking for. The bigger lecture might be a better fit for some, especially if they are concerned about the curve. However, given the smaller class size and Tolgas experienced, engaging instruction I am very happy with my choice.
